responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability in HTML templates
    analysis: |
      The template uses unescaped variables directly in the HTML code, for instance, "$lang$", "$dir$", 
      "$author-meta$", "$title-prefix$", "$pagetitle$", and many others. If these variables are supplied 
      by user input and are not properly sanitized or escaped, an attacker could inject malicious 
      JavaScript code. This code would be executed in the user's browser when they load the compromised 
      webpage. Such vulnerabilities can lead to various types of attacks, including session hijacking, 
      defacement of the webpage, and redirection to malicious sites.
    cwe: CWE-79
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - doc/template.html
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Invalid use of `innerHTML` in JavaScript
    analysis: |
      The JavaScript code assigns values to 'innerHTML' which can be dynamically generated based on user 
      input without proper sanitization. Specifically, within the script that handles collapsing elements: 
      `element.innerHTML = ...`. Direct use of `innerHTML` with user-supplied input can lead to DOM-based XSS, 
      allowing an attacker to execute arbitrary code in the client's browser.
    cwe: CWE-79
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - doc/template.html
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Use of HTTP links in conditional comments
    analysis: |
      The HTML template includes a conditional comment to load the HTML5 shiv if the Internet Explorer version 
      is less than 9. The script URL is "http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/html5shiv/3.7.3/html5shiv-printshiv.min.js". 
      Loading external resources over HTTP exposes the application to Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks where an attacker 
      could intercept and modify the content of the external resource.
    cwe: CWE-311
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - doc/template.html
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerability in HTML templates
leads.analysis:
The template uses unescaped variables directly in the HTML code, for instance, "$lang$", "$dir$", 
"$author-meta$", "$title-prefix$", "$pagetitle$", and many others. If these variables are supplied 
by user input and are not properly sanitized or escaped, an attacker could inject malicious 
JavaScript code. This code would be executed in the user's browser when they load the compromised 
webpage. Such vulnerabilities can lead to various types of attacks, including session hijacking, 
defacement of the webpage, and redirection to malicious sites.

leads.headline: Invalid use of innerHTML in JavaScript
leads.analysis:
The JavaScript code assigns values to 'innerHTML' which can be dynamically generated based on user 
input without proper sanitization. Specifically, within the script that handles collapsing elements: 
element.innerHTML = .... Direct use of innerHTML with user-supplied input can lead to DOM-based XSS, 
allowing an attacker to execute arbitrary code in the client's browser.

leads.headline: Use of HTTP links in conditional comments
leads.analysis:
The HTML template includes a conditional comment to load the HTML5 shiv if the Internet Explorer version 
is less than 9. The script URL is "http://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/html5shiv/3.7.3/html5shiv-printshiv.min.js". 
Loading external resources over HTTP exposes the application to Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks where an attacker 
could intercept and modify the content of the external resource.
